description:
Borrelia miyamotoi is a species of spirochete bacteria that belongs to the Borrelia genus. It is known to be the causative agent of a tick-borne disease in humans, often referred to as "Miyamotoi disease" or "hard tick-borne relapsing fever."

Borrelia miyamotoi is a gram-negative, spiral-shaped bacterium that is transmitted by hard-bodied ticks, primarily of the Ixodes genus. It is closely related to the Borrelia burgdorferi bacteria, which is responsible for Lyme disease, but it is a distinct species.

The infection caused by Borrelia miyamotoi is characterized by flu-like symptoms, including fever, headache, fatigue, and muscle aches. In some cases, it can also lead to a relapsing fever pattern, with recurring episodes of illness. The disease is typically more severe in immunocompromised individuals.

Borrelia miyamotoi was first identified in Japan in 1995 and has since been reported in various regions of the world, including North America, Europe, and Asia. Its geographical distribution overlaps with that of Lyme disease, and it is considered an emerging public health concern in areas where Ixodes ticks are present.

Diagnosis of Borrelia miyamotoi infection typically involves serological tests or molecular techniques, such as PCR, to detect the presence of the bacteria in clinical samples. Treatment often involves the use of antibiotics, similar to the management of Lyme disease.
